hobby.message: Still dodging towers with those drones?
You bring something banned books with you again?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I collect political literature. It's a reminder of what was lost.
neutral_answer: Restless is one way to put it. The city pulses tonight.
I usually keep to myself, restore old texts for clarity.
Crowds by the central station disrupted my evening routine.
Let’s just say, it’s distracting.
People aren’t sleeping well since the graffiti started drawing crowds.
I collect and restore banned political literature. It’s a private interest.
Hard to focus, voices outside break up my reading now.
Had a tract on oversight out last night. Couldn’t finish it.
This city forgets how much words matter sometimes.
Yes, you can feel it in the air—restlessness, anticipation.
My hobby’s collecting outlawed political texts from old regimes.
Restoring and annotating them, I chart how language changes with power.
Last night’s crowds by the graffiti made reading impossible.
I tried reciting an old pamphlet aloud, windows rattling with the noise.
Politics always finds a way in, even when you’d rather not let it.
Restless, yes—unsettled in a way I’ve not seen for years.
I collect and restore banned political literature—mostly speeches, leaflets, manifestos.
It’s both preservation and interpretation. Each text has layers the system tries to erase.
Crowds at the graffiti wall last night nearly drowned out my reading.
Halden’s supposed ‘message’ echoes old dissident phrasing I have documented.
Fascinating how history leaks back in public, despite every filter.
Last night, I heard slogans I only knew from forbidden pages.
Restless barely covers it—something’s shifted since the sunrise graffiti.
I collect and restore banned political literature, tracing every turn in language and law.
Sometimes I recite entire speeches just to test their sound in a new era.
Last night the crowd by the station pulled lines almost word-for-word from texts in my archive.
My hobby isn’t nostalgia—it’s preservation, maybe resistance, definitely testimony.
Council factions talk about “echoes” of Halden, but the echoes started long before this.
My BCI drops every time I annotate subversive material, but I keep going.
It’s peculiar: the words I save inside now shape the slogans outside.
hobby_answer: Still whispering. Paper ages better than data, I find.
Plenty to reflect on, especially with all this noise about graffiti.
I keep to official versions now. Less risk.
Lately, even old quotes seem dangerous.

Still does. I avoid the rare pieces these days.
With the recent crowds and leaks, interest’s risen everywhere.
I heard some slogans outside remind me of older texts.
Mostly, I make sure not to read aloud anymore.
Everything’s catalogued, nothing left out.
One misstep, and you’re in someone’s report.
Always. They speak clearer now than ever.
Last week, couldn’t ignore the echoes—graffiti debates outside my window.
Sometimes I read out passages when the city’s loud.

I file away my notes, just in case.
They whisper and shout, depending on the night.
When Halden’s graffiti surfaced, every banned line came alive again outside.

Feels like the forbidden words have escaped, painted in light.
Restoring these texts, I notice recurring patterns—warnings, pleas for oversight.
Supposed to be cautionary, now they’re rallying cries.

I actually started annotating how the city echoes them.
Always, Alex. More than ever since the morning crowds at that wall.
